comments.commentBody: I vote with Bob in the comment above.  People are so far unwilling to even seriously discuss the issue of reduced reproduction, the obvious and obtainable solution to the climate change scenario.   Willingness to go to this discussion separates the adults-as-children from real adults in our society.  This is a discussion that cries out for leadership, regardless of how difficult the discussion may be for many people.  It is so extremely obvious that limiting human reproduction is the answer to all this foolishness, and that nothing else will work anyway.  Who's up for at least having the discussion??

Dr. K,

I will wager that more of than half of America's school children would have a difficult time in naming and giving a short definition of three types of government and even more alarming I will go ahead and make a wager that even more parents would have a difficult time with the question.

In recent press interviews on C-SPAN, even our educated diplomats could not sort out the kind of government sought by ISIL, and the various governments currently in power in the Middle East.

The Economist should do a survey of voting age adults and presidential candidates on the Middle East and North Africa. Probably the voters would be more literate than the politicians. Remember Gerald Ford? Knowlege of the World's governments is not one of our strong suits, this is one of the problems with the TPP, TAA. We really don't know where we make our money and where the stuff that we consume comes from. Plus it is a secret in the proposed TPP. It is really bothersome that the actual mechanism for enforcing "dumping", subsidized pricing, or currency manipulation cannot be described and no one is really asking the questions. The best thus far is Senator Sanders, Republican Senator Sessions of Alabama, and DemocraticSenator Sherrod Brown of Ohio. I wish you could get C-SPAN for the next few several days.

Guns make killing easier? Really? Didn't the Waco police use guns to stop the mayhem? Seems to me like more people would have been killed if good guys had not stopped the bad guys! When you are being assaulted, are you going to call the police and tell them not to bring guns because "guns make killing easier??" I bet not.

My proposal is to ban guns IN PUBLIC by non-police.
Please do not distort.
No one is calling for banning guns.
If you want a gun for protection in your home, fine. But please keep that gun trigger locked or stored in a safe when not in use.

(CNN) -- A Kentucky mother stepped outside of her home just for a few minutes, but it was long enough for her 5-year-old son to accidentally shoot and kill his 2-year-old sister with the .22-caliber rifle he got for his birthday, state officials said.

England banned hand guns.
Death rate from guns in UK = .1 /100K.
Death rate from guns in US = 10 /100K.

Please help us understand why gun nuts in the NRA successfully had federal laws modified so violent felons [including those convicted of murder] can legally obtain guns.

see http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/14/us/felons-finding-it-easy-to-regain-gu...

Distinguish between police have guns IN PUBLIC and non-police having guns IN PUBLIC.

The belief that having everyone carrying a gun makes us all safer is nuts and not supported by the evidence.
We can obtain perspective from the Diallo case in NYC.
Diallo , an UNARMED person, was shot 41 times by 4 highly trained cops. Half the shots missed Diallo. Cops mistook shots from other cops for shots fired by Diallo.
If trained cops can make a mistake like this think what untrained vigilante gun nuts might do.
Consider the Va. Tech case. Suppose thirty students had been armed. Each pulls out his gun and starts blasting away. Scaling from the Diallo case, each student fires ten shots for a total of three hundred shots. Half [150] shots miss. Whom do these errant shots hit. Students mistake shots from other students for shots from the criminal. Students shoot at each other. A real bloodbath.

Disappointing to see so many posts devoid of basic common sense blaming everything other than the culprits. The culprits were the bikers. Guns did not make them shoot up each other. Twin Peaks did not make them shoot each other up. The state of Texas did not make them shoot each other up. Their "sad" upbringings [the "mommy" card] did not make them shoot each other up. They are fully grown violent adults who made a choice to shoot each other up. Why are so many here so confused about that?
Maybe it's because the bikers didn't try to resist and start punching cops, or try to take the cops' guns, and were nonchalant themselves.
Sir Winston Churchill is accredited with the following: "A conservative is a liberal who's been mugged.". 'Nuff said.
They will arming bears next.
Guns are marvelous and wonderful, aren't they.

They spent the money living a good life and buying nice stuff, a lot of it imported from Germany.  It seemed like magic at the time - suddenly, everybody was rich!

Before the crisis the greeks piled up 500 Billion in government debts, and 2000 billion in federal bank inbalances (also known as target2), government debts were already cut in half to 240 Billion Euro (320 Billion would be dollars).
Most of the money was spend on funding a economy that needed permanently subsidized. But a huge part of the wealth is now in the hands of the oligarchs who simple have withdrawn the money. Swiss has summed up, that greeks have untaxed accounts of 700 Billion just in their country ( http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-02-04/greece-seeks-deal-on-s... )
Very flowery, but correct.

Wow! This read like a Wikipedian interpretation of "Westside Story".  And I FINALLY got it! Really! A co-worker worried about where and HOW they were going to house hundreds of rival gang members without them killing each other??? And I IMMEDIATELY thought, We should leave the gates open, throw in some rusty pipes and let them have at it. Who cares if they die? WOW!!!  How could I?! Who AM I?!?! *GASP!!!* Am I racist?! *pearls CLUTHED* is this how..."they" feel?? To cast a judgement so easily because I am magnanimous and "they" are, so obviously, such bad people? Is this what that power, that entitlement, feels like? Wow. Niiiccceee. I see why "they" do it, now.

Because they were scared because they were heavily out gunned.

The Waco Cops would have done better by clearing the shopping plaza of customers of other stores and restaurant and "letting the chips fall where they may". That is, essentially what that the LAPD did during the first days of the 1992 Los Angeles riots.

Heaven help the spouses of Texas law men (and their public pension fund) when, someday, two enemy Mexican drug cartels go to war in El Paso, Brownsville, Corpus Christi, San Antonio or Houston. They need to learn from the NYPD in the days of the Mafia wars and just stay out of it.

I noticed the same thing...the PR officer's statement was that they "may have fired" on police, and police may have been responsible for "several of those killed."
Is several 6-8 people, of the 8 people dead?
Does this mean we will discover that all the deceased died by bullets from police weapons. Is shooting first, in every situation, the only recourse in this country?
When I made my comment, I allowed that bikers are not kindegartners, and nobody is saying the situation wasn't inherently dangerous, but the fight seemed to progress from fists, and feet and chains (possibly knives, though I haven't heard of knife fatalities reported), to bullets.
When did this happen?
I hope it wasn't when the police arrived, and began shooting...
I apologize, my comment was meant for another post, under the name of John Neely.
How safe would it be if ARMED policemen had not stopped them with their firearms?
Guess so, unless you're trying to shot fellow bikers or cops- all bets are off!
Gee, I thought if everyone had firearms then the world would be a safer place....right? Guess not.
Not following your reasoning about the Times commenters. Are you saying that liberals are usually on the side of gang motorcyclists?
Bushbama is their friend, but you can see how they'd be confused.
They make less per hour than most city government workers once actual hours worked, bonuses, and benefits are included.

John: How is fighting for clean water "destructive to our national defense, our national finances, and our national values"? Would you favor government intervention if ISIL or Al Qaeda were trying to foul our water supply?

It will indeed take "decades to recover" from Republican assaults on the environment.
Ron, you mis-spelled "inefficiency" among other errors.  You might consider taking some of your own advice.

I think the EPA has flouted 18USC1913, but members of Congress have been doing that for years with their official Facebook pages. However, given the obscene amounts of money big business has to fight environmental regulations, we need some balance in the system.

And the EPA and the government generally are not tasked with protecting the business interests of the fertilizer and pesticide industries, oil and gas producers and Big Ag, although it sure seems as though many politicians and businesses have completely lost sight of that fact.

"The Farm Bureau was supported by home builders, the fertilizer and pesticide industries, oil and gas producers and a national association of golf course owners who collectively called for the E.P.A. to revamp or withdraw its proposal."

I am glad that finally, and for once, the Obama administration placed the people's interest above the lobbyists', with this EPA rule to protect our water supply.

Or do you believe the fertilizer and pesticide industries, oil and gas producers and Big Ag have the public's health foremost in their mind?

The Environemtnal Protection Agency is tasked to protect the environement and thereby our health. The the fertilizer and pesticide industries, oil and gas producers are not.

This vitiates the purpose of the public comment requirement concerning proposed regulations. If the regulators are allowed to "stack the deck" for the purpose of drowning out any contrary views or negative comments, there's no purpose in having the comment period.

This is not a Republican versus Democrat, conservative versus liberal or business versus environmental group issue. This is about making sure that non-elected officials are required to solicit AND CONSIDER public input before enacting rules that affect both supporters and opponents of the proposal.
Wait, why are you undercutting your own argument?
They're building homes they can sell at a profit.  What happens after they pocket that to the people who live in the homes?  Not their concern.
It does not really make sense for the Home Builders Association to protest clean water measures. After all, they are building homes for people to live in and people prefer clean water.

Chris (sorry, not Clyde!) Lydle: Apparently the censors relented. You have a powerful influence after all.

It would help if you would address your replies to specific comments; I can't make out what you're trying to say because there's no context. Please do so.

You can post a non-liberal comment at the Times. If it's missing the point or totally insensitive to the issue, you'll get a lot of feedback that you won't like. It doesn't mean there's a knee-jerk liberal reaction; it means you should think more deeply. In this particular case, any photograph of an armored vehicle with a sniper at the ready on its top, flanked by lines of armored police with drawn guns, would immediately make one expect a well-armed gang on the other side, but it was a peaceful protest. I saw this on a related article today. I am sorry I don't remember the article. That is precisely the type of bad policing the commenters here are trying to tell you about, some of them very politely.
